stream_context.summary: Kaze works on a Bowser-themed industrial level, focusing on visual polish and performance. Key activities include integrating a new switch model from artist Biobak, extensive performance testing on N64 hardware, and dedicating a majority of the stream to developing a novel graphical technique for a vast, convincing ocean background.

development_findings.summary: A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to solving how to render a vast ocean background. After failed attempts with standard techniques, Kaze developed a novel solution using a 3D plane that moves with the camera to create a parallax effect.
development_findings.quote: I feel like an NBG doesn't work if the elements in your level are touching the skybox. I think that's a rule of thumb here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered his models were being exported inefficiently, doubling the polygon count. Despite this, the game was still running at a stable 30 FPS on N64 hardware during tests, highlighting the project's performance.
development_findings.quote: I was exporting it as an F3D model and not F3DEX2. So we had twice the vertex loads, twice the triangle counts... and it still ran fine.

development_findings.summary: Performance on N64 hardware for the complex level was tested, hitting 22 FPS in the most demanding area before planned optimizations like backface culling, triangle sorting, and collision map generation are implemented.
Kaze chose to use a P-switch for a level mechanic specifically because it is a recurring design element in Bowser levels in the original Super Mario 64, maintaining thematic consistency.
development_findings.quote: Every Bowser level in Mario 64 uses this exact switch to help Mario beat the stage. This is just a very Mario 64 Bowser design.

development_findings.summary: The project uses a community-made patch ('Matrix Stack Fix' by Wiseguy) to implement proper world-based directional lighting, overcoming a core rendering limitation of the original SM64 engine.
Kaze found and fixed a long-standing stability bug that caused his previous project (Only Up 64) to crash, resulting in a much more stable experience for this game on original hardware.

context_findings.summary: Kaze was approached by a merchandising company, sparking the idea of a business model selling legal physical merchandise like N64-style boxes and separate OST ROMs.
context_findings.quote: Dude, when I sell RTYI, I could just sell the box without the ROM, and it'd be legal. And then I would also make a ROM that's just the OST and sell that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze balances the development of the game with a full-time programming job.
context_findings.quote: I have a full-time job on the side. So that's why I don't have too much time to just work on this all the time.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared his programming philosophy, expressing a strong preference for the C language over C++, with the exception of its 'tolerable' templates.
context_findings.quote: I think C++ is just a shitty version of C. Here's my hot take for the day.

context_findings.summary: Kaze was approached for his opinion regarding a drama in the beta Mario 64 romhacking community, indicating his prominent status within the scene.
Kaze intends to financially compensate contributors, including artists and musicians, if the project generates revenue.
context_findings.quote: If the set makes decent money, I have to pay you. I completely agree. I was offering to pay the musicians as well, for like the rights to the music, once everything's done.

biobak.summary: Biobak designed and provided a new, high-quality 3D model for the P-switch, which Kaze integrated and praised as a perfect upgrade.
biobak.quote: This is so much better than the one we had before. This actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time feedback on the level's background, suggesting a color gradient for the horizon to blend the ocean and sky, which influenced the final design.

zeina.summary: Zeina's role as an animator was mentioned; she is working on a character animation for the level being developed.
zeina.quote: Unfortunately Zeina's gone today. Otherwise, she maybe would have finished the animation for the guy here.

key_stories.title: Creating the Infinite Ocean Background
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to create a convincing infinite ocean background that worked within N64 limitations. After his initial idea failed, he collaborated with feedback from his chat to pioneer a new technique involving a parallaxing 3D plane, ultimately achieving the desired vast-ocean effect.
key_stories.challenge: The level, an industrial island, needed a background that felt like a vast, endless ocean. N64 hardware limitations made rendering a huge body of water without visual artifacts or an abrupt, visible edge a major problem.
key_stories.process: Kaze first tried a standard near background (NBG), but it failed because level geometry touched it, creating a 'painted on' look. He then tried warping the 3D model of the water, which also looked wrong. Following feedback from his team, he implemented the final solution: a large 3D plane for the ocean that moves at 85-95% of the camera's speed, creating a convincing illusion of distance.
key_stories.outcome: After extensive trial and error, Kaze developed a successful technique using a separate 3D plane that moves with the camera to create a parallax effect. This gave the illusion of an infinite ocean, solving the visual and technical problem to his satisfaction.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh yes, that is what I want. Oh that is so much nicer.

key_stories.title: The Upgraded Switch Model
key_stories.summary: Kaze was unsatisfied with the quality of the original P-switch model. Artist Biobak provided a new, custom-made model that was a significant visual upgrade while remaining faithful to the original. Kaze integrated it, praising it as a perfect replacement.
key_stories.challenge: The standard P-switch from Mario 64 had flawed UV mapping and looked dated. Kaze wanted a visually improved asset that was still faithful to the original game's style.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the visual flaws in the original Nintendo model. While he was considering how to fix it, team member Biobak independently created a new, higher-quality 3D model and sent it over. Kaze imported the model, confirmed it was well-optimized, and integrated it into the level.
key_stories.outcome: The new switch model from Biobak was immediately adopted, replacing the old one. It served as a perfect, high-quality asset that elevated the level's visual polish while respecting the original game's design language.
key_stories.key_quote: This is so much better than the one we had before. This actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one.
